I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) has requested that the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  provide  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  a  railway  emergency 
management  system  study.  The  Fact-Finding  Mission  visited  the  PRC  in  June  2007  and 
reached  an  understanding  with  the  Government  on  the  TA  objectives,  scope,  terms  of 
reference, cost estimates, financing plan, and implementation arrangements. The TA is included 
in the ADB 2007 country program for the PRC.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  From 1978, when market-oriented economic reforms were introduced, through to 2006, 
the PRC experienced sustained rapid economic growth, which resulted in a corresponding rapid 
increase in demand for transportation. The annual growth of passenger transport was 9% and 
that of freight transport was 7.6% during the 1978–2005 period. In 2005, road traffic accounted 
for 53.2% of total passenger-kilometers (km), followed by railways with 34.7%, civil aviation with 
11.7%, and coastal and inland waterways with 0.4%. The modal split for freight ton-km was 
61.3% for coastal and inland waterways, 26.5% for railways, 11% for roads, 1.1% for pipelines, 
and 0.1% for civil aviation. 
 
3.  The railway is the primary mode of transport for long distance and bulk transport in the 
PRC, and the rapid economic growth has resulted in a corresponding high demand for railway 
transportation. At the end of 2006, the PRC’s railway system comprised 77,000 route-km and 
annually carries about one third of the total freight and passenger traffic in the PRC. Between 
1978 and 2006, railway freight grew from 535 billion ton-km to 2,172 billion ton-km, equivalent to 
an  annual  growth  rate  of  5.1%.  Passenger  traffic  grew  at  6.6%  annually,  increasing  from 
109 billion passenger-km to 666.2 billion passenger-km.  
 
4.  The Government's policy on railway development is focused on (i) removing constraints 
and expanding the capacity of the system, (ii) encouraging the construction of joint-venture local 
railways to promote the development of local economies, (iii) improving the efficiency and safety 
of the existing system by using new technology and modern management tools in planning and 
operation,  (iv)  reducing  operating  subsidies  through  appropriate  pricing  and  the 
commercialization  of  services,  (v)  initiating  institutional  and  structural  reforms  to  increase 
autonomy and accountability, and (vi) encouraging nongovernment investment in infrastructure 
and related  services.  
 
5.  The Tenth Five-Year Plan (2001–2005) identified railway development as a priority. By 
the end of the Plan, an investment of CNY308 billion had been made for capital construction, 
which included (i) constructing 6,458 km of new lines; (ii) providing 3,275 km of double lines; 
and (iii) electrifying 6,259 km of tracks. The Railway Development Plan (2004) seeks to expand 
the railway network to 100,000 km by 2020. 
 
6.  The Eleventh Five-Year Plan (2006–2010) continues to emphasize railway development, 
and seeks to speed up railway construction. The plan envisages (i) constructing 17,000 km of 
new lines with the network length reaching over 90,000 route-km; and (ii) increasing the length 
of the double lines and electrified lines to reach 45% of the network length. The plan seeks to (i)

build a dedicated passenger railway network by constructing passenger dedicated lines, (ii) 
develop coal transport corridors by increasing the capacity of existing lines, (iii) expand the 
railway network to 34,000 km in the poor western region, (iv) build international corridors at the 
borders in the southwest and northwest, and (v) develop a countrywide intermodal container 
network. The total estimated investments are CNY1.5 trillion or about $190 billion over the next 
5-year period. 
 
7.  ADB's strategy for the PRC railway sector focuses on (i) expanding the railway system 
by constructing new lines in unserved areas that are less-developed and poor; (ii) promoting 
energy conservation and environmental sustainability and/or promoting regional cooperation; 
(iii) modernizing equipment, enhancing safety, and increasing the capacity to improve transport 
efficiency on key routes of the national railway system; (iv) commercializing railway operations 
to sustain efficient operations; and (v) increasing railway competitiveness in the transport sector 
through restructuring and reform.  
 
8.  ADB,  the  lead  development  partner  in  the  PRC  railway  sector,  has  focused  on 
developing railways in less-developed inland provinces to promote growth and reduce poverty. 
ADB provided 14 loans, totaling about $2.9 billion, to finance the construction of about 1,921 km 
of provincial railways and 5,541 km of national railway projects. The World Bank has provided 
11 loans totaling over $2.6 billion since 1984 for (i) 10 national railway projects to expand 
railway capacity on high-priority corridors, modernize system-wide technology, and strengthen 
institutional capabilities; and (ii) one local railway project. Japan is the major source of external 
financing in the PRC railway sector. Since 1979, it has provided about Y558 billion for 15 
railway projects to expand rail transportation capacity.   
 
9.  Policy dialogue has been a significant component of ADB assistance to the railway 
sector and has effectively complemented the lending operations. Since 2002, there has been an 
active engagement in policy dialogue and discussion with the Ministry of Railways (MOR), 
National Development Reform Commission (NDRC), and Ministry of Finance (MOF) and there 
is a broad agreement  on reforms as an engine to further development of railways in the 
transport sector. Thirteen TA grants to PRC railways since 1989 have been for policy reforms, 
institutional  development  (local  railways,  dedicated  passenger  lines),  strengthening  of 
commercial and business operations, marketing and business development, tariff setting with 
improved cost recovery, developing human resources, and improving financial management 
and accounting systems. ADB policy dialogue continues to emphasize further progress in those 
areas.  In  recent  years,  ADB  policy  dialogue  has  been  emphasizing  enhanced  safety, 
environmental sustainability, and energy conservation.  
 
10.  Safety  is  an  important  aspect  of  reliable  transportation  and  critical  to  providing  a 
competitive, high-quality, and safe mode of transport to people and goods. As PRC railways 
have modernized and introduced new concepts and technologies, safety needs have changed. 
ADB  policy  dialogue  with  MOR  emphasizes  the  need  for  higher  standards  of  safety  in 
construction,  operation,  and  maintenance.  Since  2003,  ADB  has  supported  investments  in 
railway safety as part of ADB financing. ADB initiated dialogue on adopting a sector-wide 
approach on safety rather than a project-based approach. Adopting a sector-wide approach is 
consistent with the network approach adopted for train operations in the PRC and helps in 
providing economies of scale, and better management of emergencies, preventive maintenance 
and accidents. ADB is working closely with MOR to develop a comprehensive plan emphasizing

3 
institutional, investment, and training needs of MOR. ADB is proposing to finance a Railway 
Safety Enhancement Project ($100 million) in 20072.  
 
11.  An important element of the sector-wide approach to safety is the management of 
various  kinds  of  emergencies,  disasters,  and  accidents  at  different  levels  of  management 
(ministry,  railway  administration,  and  railway  station).  MOR  has  an  established  system  of 
handling railway accidents at the three levels. However, the system to deal with emergencies 
and natural disasters like earthquakes, typhoons, or other natural calamities is in a nascent 
stage. It was only after the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 2003 that 
MOR for the first time planned the setting up at the national level of a mechanism to deal with 
natural disasters and major emergencies such as earthquakes, typhoons, and other natural 
calamities. MOR made a beginning in 2005 by establishing an emergency management office 
directly under the control of the Minister (as part of the Minister’s office). In 2006, an emergency 
management center was established under the transportation department.  
 
12.  Simultaneously,  the  pace  of  modernization  and  technological  development  in  PRC 
railways has quickened. In April 2007, train speeds were raised to 200 km/hour (h) and 250 
km/h after the sixth speedup. In 2008, the Beijing–Tianjin dedicated passenger line, with a 
speed of 300km/h, will be put into operation. Train speeds on dedicated passenger lines will be 
increased to 300–350 km/h by 2010. Trains with higher trailing loads have been introduced on 
the  Daqin  railway  line.  MOR  seeks  to  introduce  double-stack  container  operation  under 
electrified traction on the Shanghai–Chengdu corridor by 2012.  
 
13.  All  these  developments,  combined  with  the  critical  role  played  by  railways  in  the 
economic  development  of  the  country  and  the  demand  for  high  standards  of  safety  and 
reliability, have imposed new challenges for MOR. Managing emergencies and crises on a 
technologically advanced high-speed railway system is a new concept for PRC railways, and 
managing such a network is different from managing the conventional railway system. MOR has 
little or no experience in emergency and crisis management and therefore seeks to learn from 
international experience and best practices. Given this background, the Government and MOR 
requested ADB assistance in researching and learning from best international practices on 
emergency management systems in advanced railway systems in developed countries and help 
in adapting them to PRC railways.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The impact of the proposed TA is an efficient, safe, reliable, and competitive railway 
transport system developed in the PRC.  The outcome of the TA will be a plan for an efficient 
and effective railway emergency management system (EMS) that can be adopted by MOR. The 
TA will (i) review the current practices adopted by MOR for managing railway emergencies; (ii) 
research best international practices and experiences in railway EMSs; and (iii) recommend 
actions for developing an efficient and effective railway EMS, which should be realistic for the 
Government and MOR to implement. Appendix 1 gives the design and monitoring framework.

4 
The study will make use of experience in other railways and involve the active participation of 
railway management.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
15.  To achieve the objective, the consultants will (i) compare and analyze the EMS in 
developed  countries  such  as  Japan,  France,  and  Germany  by  (a)  reviewing  the  working 
principles, mechanism, system, institutional structure, and methodology of EMS in each of those 
countries, and (b) identifying the comparative advantages of each system through a strengths 
and weaknesses analysis that will include reviewing the features, performance, and experience 
of  using  these  systems;  (ii)  recommend  regulations,  rules,  working  principles,  mechanism, 
institutional  structure,  methodology,  technology,  maintenance  practices  and  needs,  and 
personnel and training needs for an EMS that can be adopted in the PRC; and (iii) provide 
capacity-building support through international and domestic training and knowledge transfer. 
The consultants will make use of experience in other railways (international), involve active 
participation of railway management, implement domestic and international training programs, 
and recommend a set of actions that can help MOR to set up an efficient and effective EMS for 
PRC railways. The recommendations should be realistic for the Government and MOR to 
implement.  
 
16.  The TA will be undertaken in close consultation with the Government, MOR, and other 
relevant agencies. The study will build on ADB’s ongoing policy dialogue. It will consider all 
previous  studies  by  the  Government,  ADB,  World  Bank,  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-
operation and Development, other multilateral agencies, and bilateral agencies. The TA will 
involve research; fieldwork; training; and stakeholder consultations with the Government, the 
private sector, user groups, and international development partners. 
 
17.  Key activities will include a review of existing studies by MOR, the Government, and 
other multilateral institutions; data analysis; and consultation with other stakeholders. Capacity- 
building support will be provided through an international training program and a domestic 
training  program,  with  participation  from  relevant  departments,  to  learn  from  international 
experiences  and  best  practices  of  railways  overseas.  Workshops,  one  each  at  inception, 
interim, and draft final report stages of TA implementation, will be organized to discuss and 
review the findings of the study, and a seminar will be organized at the final report stage to 
disseminate TA findings.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $630,000 equivalent. ADB’s TA funding program 
will finance the TA on a grant basis in the amount of $500,000. MOR will finance the remaining 
$130,000 equivalent, which will be used to cover office accommodation and the counterpart 
staff required to implement the TA. The detailed cost estimate is in Appendix 2.    
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  MOR, as the Executing Agency, will be responsible for supervising and monitoring TA 
activities. A leading group comprising representatives of relevant departments of MOR will be 
set up to oversee implementation and provide guidance and direction to the consultants. In 
addition, MOR will appoint a project coordinator who will supervise and coordinate day-to-day

5 
TA  activities,  including  monitoring  progress,  resolving  problems,  arranging  meetings,  and 
liaising with the government agencies concerned. To facilitate the work of the consultants, and 
to ensure that MOR benefits from their experience, MOR will provide adequate counterpart staff 
with relevant work experience during TA implementation. MOR will also provide policy guidance 
to the consultants. Workshops and a seminar will be held to review findings at the inception, 
interim, and final stages of the TA. These meetings will include representatives of MOR, MOF, 
other  relevant  agencies,  ADB,  and  the  consultants.  A  final  report  will  be  published  at  TA 
completion. 
 
20.  A consulting firm will be engaged by ADB using simplified technical proposal procedures 
and the quality- and cost-based selection method in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time) and other arrangements satisfactory 
to ADB for engaging national consultants. The TA will require about 14 person-months of 
international and about 9 person-months of national consulting services to carry out the terms of 
reference (Appendix 3). The international consultants will have expertise and experience in the 
following fields of railway transport relating to emergency and crisis management systems: (i) the 
concept, organization, working principles, mechanism, design and implementation; (ii) network 
development and management, information and communication systems, and technical issues; 
and (iii) regulation, rules, and institutional issues. The national consultants will have expertise and 
experience in the following fields of railway transport relating to emergency management and 
crisis  management  systems  in  the  PRC:  (i)  concept,  organization,  working  mechanism;  (ii) 
network management, information and communication systems, and technical issues in the PRC; 
and (iii) regulation, rules, and institutional issues. The TA is expected to begin in November 2007 
and  be  completed  by  May  2008.  Procurement  of  equipment,  supplies,  and  materials  by 
consultants under the TA will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time 
to time). The equipment will be turned over to MOR after TA completion. 
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Railway Emergency Management 
System Study, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Services 
 
1.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for a 
railway emergency management system study will help the Government and the Ministry of 
Railways (MOR) to prepare a plan for an efficient and effective railway emergency management 
system for PRC railways. The TA will (i) review the current practices adopted by MOR for 
managing railway emergencies; (ii) research best international practices and experiences in 
railway  emergency  management  systems;  and  (iii)  recommend  actions  for  developing  an 
efficient and effective railway emergency management system, which will be realistic for the 
Government and MOR to implement. The study (i) will make use of similar studies undertaken 
by MOR, experience in other railways (international), case studies in other countries; (ii) involve 
active participation of railway management; and (iii) recommend a set of actions that can help 
MOR in setting up an emergency management system for PRC railways. The TA will also 
support capacity building through international and domestic training programs and knowledge 
transfer. 
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
2.  The tasks under the TA will include, but will not necessarily be limited to, the following 
specific tasks. 
 
3.  Emergency and Crisis Management Specialists (5 person-months international and 3 
person-months national). The specialists will undertake a comprehensive review of the existing 
emergency management system (EMS) of the railway network in the PRC, and analyze and 
compare it with the emergency and/or crisis management system in developed countries like 
France, Germany, and Japan. The specialists will review the principles, institutional structure, 
mechanism,  system,  maintenance  principles,  and  methodology  of  EMS  in  each  of  those 
countries; and identify the comparative advantages of the system in each country through a 
strengths and weaknesses analysis that will include reviewing the features, performance, and 
experience of using such systems. On the basis of the review, the consultants will recommend a 
system  that  can  be  adopted  for  PRC  railways.  The  review  will  include  assessment  of 
preparedness, management team organization and responsibilities, communications, specific 
emergency response procedures; and recovery, restoration, and mitigation measures to be 
adopted in case of emergencies and crises. The recommendations will (i) explain the method, 
basis, process, and models of EMS that can be adopted, taking into account issues like network 
capacity,  traffic  demand,  traffic  flows,  maintenance  practices,  technological  advancements, 
geographical condition and other operating parameters; and (ii) include suggestions on the 
principles, mechanism, institutional structure, maintenance practices and needs, staffing and 
training  needs  of  EMS  to  manage  and  respond  to  emergencies  or  crises  under  varying 
situations. As team leader, the international specialist, together with the network communication 
and information specialists and the legal and regulatory specialists, will prepare a plan that will 
recommend  the  regulations,  rules,  working  principles,  mechanism,  institutional  structure, 
methodology, maintenance and technology needs, and personnel and training needs for a 
system that can be adopted by MOR for PRC railways.

Appendix 3           9 
4.  Network  Communication  and  Information  Management  Specialists  (4  person-
months international and 3 person-months national). The specialists will examine the existing 
system of network communication and information system relating to the EMS of the railway 
network in the PRC, and analyze and compare it with similar systems in developed countries 
like France, Germany, and Japan. The specialists will (i) review the principles, mechanism, 
system and methodology of the network communication and information system for EMS in 
each of those countries; (ii) identify the comparative advantages of the respective system in 
each country through a strengths and weaknesses analysis that will include reviewing the 
features, performance and experience of using these systems; and (iii) on the basis of the 
review recommend a system that can be adopted for PRC railways.  The recommendations will 
(i) explain the method, basis, process, and models that can be adopted, taking into account 
issues like capacity of the network communication and information system, compatibility with  
technical standards, interfacing with existing technologies and technical standards, compatibility 
with  existing  PRC  communication  and  information  system  standards  and  other  operating 
parameters; and (ii) include suggestions on the principles, mechanism, institutional structure, 
maintenance principles and needs, staffing and training needs for EMS to manage and respond 
to emergencies or crises under varying situations. The consultants will make recommendations 
on management team organization and responsibilities, emergency response, recovery, and 
mitigation measures to be adopted in case of emergencies and crises.  
 
5.  Legal, Regulatory, and Institutional Specialists (5 person-months for international 
and 3 person-months for national). The specialists will review existing rules, regulations, and 
institutional structure for EMS of the railway network in the PRC, and analyze and compare 
them with the rules, regulations, and institutional structure in developed countries like France, 
Germany, and Japan. The specialists will (i) review the efficacy of the rules, regulations, and 
institutional structure in those countries; (ii) identify the comparative advantages of the system in 
each country, through a strengths and weaknesses analysis that will include reviewing the 
features and experience of using these rules and regulations, and the institutional setup in 
providing an efficient and effective EMS in each of those countries; and (iii) on the basis of the 
review recommend (a) rules and regulations, and (b) an institutional structure that can be 
adopted for EMS for PRC railways. The recommendations on rules and regulations should be 
consistent and compatible with the national rules and regulations in the PRC for EMS and 
should clearly explain the process of how the recommended rules and regulations can be 
interfaced with the national ones. The institutional structure should consider responsibilities at 
the three levels of railway management (ministry, regional administration, and railway station) 
and  the  recommendations  should  state  their  respective  responsibilities,  and  how  such 
responsibilities can be interfaced with responsibilities of other ministries such as the Ministry of 
Public Security, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Environment, and provincial governments. The 
recommendations will also include suggestions on staffing and training needs to be integrated 
into the EMS system that will be developed to manage and respond to emergencies or crises 
under varying situations.  
 
6.  Capacity Development. The consultants will provide capacity-building support through 
international and domestic training and knowledge transfer in each of the three areas of the 
study. The international training program will include a visit to France, Germany, and Japan to 
learn from the best international experiences for a period of 15 days and will involve 12–15 
officials  of  the  relevant  departments  of  MOR.  The  consultants  will  also  organize  a  5-day 
domestic training program for 60 persons, to explain the concepts, the study research report,

10  Appendix 3 
and the recommendations for EMS for PRC railways. The training program will be organized in 
close coordination with MOR. The contents of the two training programs and list of participants 
will require ADB approval. 
 
7.  The consultants will organize workshops at the inception, interim, and draft final report 
stages of the TA to discuss the findings and outputs of the respective reports; and will organize 
a seminar, after submitting the final report, to disseminate the findings and outcome of the TA. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements  
 
8.  The  consultants  will  submit  the  following reports:  (i)  inception  report  2  weeks after 
services begin, (ii) interim report after 12 weeks, (iii) draft final report after 20 weeks, and  
(iv) final report (including key findings and recommendations [5 pages]) after 6 months. MOR 
requires five copies of each report in English and Chinese while the Ministry of Finance (TA 
Division) needs two copies of each report in English and Chinese. ADB requires five copies of 
each report in English. The final report will be edited for publication (bilingual). All reports will be 
submitted in both hard copy and soft copy.
